metadata.title: Appendix: COVID-19 on the African continent

body_text.text: Using an age-structured epidemiological model, we simulated a COVID-19 outbreak in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) in the absence of any social distancing to estimate the total number of COVID-19 infections and deaths. We consider the age classes of 0-19, 20-49, 50-64, and 65+.

We account for age-dependent contact patterns for the transmission dynamics in the general population ( G ) and contact patterns in the home ( H ). With no available information on the contact patterns specific to the DRC, we utilize the contact patterns of the neighboring Republic of Congo (Table A2-A3). 1 Once a susceptible individual ( S ) is infected, they enter the incubation period ( E ) for an average of 1/ days. After the incubation period, a proportion i of COVID-19 cases exhibit severe/critical infection ( C ) and the remaining fraction experience midler symptoms ( I ). We assume that the average duration of the infectious period is the same for both mild and severe/critical cases, with the infectious period lasting 1/ days. For individuals experiencing severe/critical illness, we assume that their symptoms are severe enough that after 1/ days they will reside in their home for the remaining part of their infectious period. For the average time from onset to staying at home (1/ ), we use one day which is the time from symptom onset to fever 2 . Since we assumed the duration of the infectious period was the same for all severities of infection, the average time a severely ill COVID-19 case spends at home is 1/ -1/ days, which corresponds to a rate of /( -).

We calibrate the transmission rate ( ) to obtain the basic reproductive number R 0 , which is obtained through the calculation of the next generation matrix. This calibration was done under the assumption that severe/critical cases do not enter their home (i.e. i =0). Our predictions for the number of infections and deaths assume that individuals exhibiting severe/critical symptoms stay at home 24 hours after symptom onset (i.e. i > 0). We found that the epidemic could be mitigated when individuals with severe/critical COVID-19 infections enter their home 24 hrs after symptom onset and R 0 < 1.15. We estimated the average case fatality ratio for the four age classes using the population demographics for the DRC 3 . To obtain the estimate for our four age classes, we utilized empirical estimates of age dependent case fatality ratios from 0 to 80+, at ten year intervals (i.e. 0-9) 4 . We apply this average case fatality ratio for the four age classes to evaluate the projected number of deaths from the predicted number of cases provided from the model.

body_text.section: Estimation of the number of infections and deaths

body_text.text: To evaluate these cumulative numbers, we simulated the model 10 5 days to allow the outbreak to run its course for all values of R 0 . To obtain a point estimate for our results, we calculated the average basic reproductive number from the point estimate values of 135 studies 5 . The uncertainty in our estimate of cumulative cases and deaths is based on the 95% confidence interval of the mean basic reproductive number. We estimated an average basic reproductive number of 2.72 (95% CI: 2.56 -2.87).
